description: From Middle English slogh, slugh, slouh, from Proto-Germanic *sluk-, perhaps related to *sleupanƒÖ (‚Äúto slip, sneak‚Äù) (compare Gothic êçÉêåªêåπêåøêçÄêå∞êåΩ (sliupan)).
Akin to Middle Low German sl√¥ (‚Äúsheath, skin on a hoof‚Äù). Perhaps also related with Old Saxon sl≈´k (‚Äúsnakeskin‚Äù), Middle High German sl≈´ch, whence German Schlauch (‚Äúwaterskin, hose‚Äù).

entries.meaning: The skin shed by a snake or other reptile.
examples: That is the slough of a rattler; we must be careful.

entries.meaning: Dead skin on a sore or ulcer.
examples: This is the slough that came off of his skin after the burn.

verbs.description: slough (third-person singular simple present sloughs, present participle sloughing, simple past and past participle sloughed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To slide off (like a layer of skin).
examples: A week after he was burned, a layer of skin on his arm sloughed off.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang, Western US) To commit truancy, be absent from school without permission.

description: From Old English sl≈çh, probably from Proto-Germanic *sl≈çhaz.

entries.meaning: (Eastern United States) A type of swamp or shallow lake system, typically formed as or by the backwater of a larger waterway, similar to a bayou with trees.
examples: We paddled under a canopy of trees through the slough.

entries.meaning: (Western United States) A secondary channel of a river delta, usually flushed by the tide.
examples: The Sacramento River Delta contains dozens of sloughs that are often used for water-skiing and fishing.

entries.meaning: (Canadian Prairies) A small pond, often alkaline, many but not all formed by glacial potholes.
examples: Potholes or sloughs formed by a glacier‚Äôs retreat from the central plains of North America, are now known to be some of the world‚Äôs most productive ecosystems.
